subject.S: REMINDER – Confirm your address with NHS England

message.S:
Dear ((fullName))

## Confirm your address with NHS England
 
We recently wrote to you to confirm if the home address the NHS holds for you is up to date.

### Please ignore this reminder if you have previously responded.

If you do not confirm your address details within 30 days, we will assume you have moved. We will begin the process of removing you from your GP surgery's patient list.

This means you will no longer be registered with a GP surgery. You will not get important information about your healthcare.

The NHS currently holds the following address for you:

### ((address))

Do not reply to this email as your response will not be processed.

## If your address information is correct
Please complete one of the following options:
 
### Option 1
Select the link and complete the online form to confirm your address. You will need:

- your reference number ((PCSERef))

- NHS number ((nhsNumber))

https://pcse.england.nhs.uk/contact-us/patient-registrations-enquiry-categories/list-cleansing-patients-only
 
### Option 2
Text YES((PCSERef)) to 07860 055388 (usual contract charges will apply).

## If your address information is incorrect

* You may need to register with a new GP surgery. You can use [Find a GP](https://www.nhs.uk/service-search/find-a-gp/) to look for a practice in your area. You can also contact your GP surgery to update your address.
* If you have left the United Kingdom and you do not plan to return in 3 months, you need to call your GP and ask them to remove you from their patient list.

This message has also been sent to you in a letter.

Tell us about your experience of confirming or updating your address by completing a [short survey](https://feedback.digital.nhs.uk/jfe/form/SV_23vNIxwRjSFmXFY).

Thank you for taking the time to respond to this request.

Yours sincerely  
Primary Care Support England   https://pcse.england.nhs.uk/organisations/public/

---
Primary Care Support England provides administrative and support services for primary care on behalf of NHS England and is part of Capita plc.

message.S: **test**

# Placeholder message for onboarding to the NHS App

Dear ((fullName)),

You need to review and update your home address with the NHS.

It is important to keep your address up to date. The NHS and your GP may use it to contact you about health checks, vaccinations or appointments.

Your current address with the NHS is:

((address))

## What you need to do

Review and update your address online at: https://confirm-your-address.account.nhs.uk

This should take less than 5 minutes, and your NHS record will be updated immediately.

## If you do not respond

If you do not update your address within the next 30 days, we will start the process of removing you from your GP surgery’s patient list.

This is to protect your personal information and stop letters from being sent to the wrong address.

We may also send you messages by email, text message and letter.

## Why we have contacted you

We regularly check patient addresses to make sure they are correct.

We have contacted you because we believe your address may be wrong. This might be because you have moved house or left the UK.

## Need help?

You can find out more about updating your address on the NHS website at: nhs.uk/gp-registrations

Kind regards,  
NHS England

subject.S: Don’t miss your chance to have your say about your local NHS services

message.S:
Dear ((firstName)) ((lastName)),

We are emailing to let you know that you only have until Tuesday 9 September to sign up to the online Health Insight Survey. If you have already completed the survey, thank you. If not, we have included a reminder about how to sign up.

This initial short survey asks questions about who you are and where you live.

##How to take part online  
Complete the steps below on your computer, tablet or smartphone.
1. Go to [https://studies.ons.gov.uk/s/healthinsightsurvey1/](https://studies.ons.gov.uk/s/healthinsightsurvey1/)
2. Complete the survey.
3. Select “Finish survey”.

##How to take part on the phone  
To take part over the phone, call us free on 0808 196 1270.

If you need advice or help, email [health.studies@ons.gov.uk](health.studies@ons.gov.uk).

The information you give us is protected by law and is treated as confidential.

##Why should you take part?  
By taking part in the Health Insight Survey, you will help to make the NHS better for all. The survey influences national policies, as well as facilities and healthcare services local to you. Your answers will help shape the future of the NHS in England.

##About the Health Insight Survey  
The Health Insight Survey is about your experiences of accessing NHS healthcare services in England. This includes your GP practice, hospital waiting lists, community health services, pharmacy and dental services. The survey takes between 5 and 10 minutes to finish.

Find out more about the Health Insight Survey on the ONS website at [https://www.ons.gov.uk/healthinsightsurvey](https://www.ons.gov.uk/healthinsightsurvey).

##Don’t miss the chance to have your say about your local NHS services.

Thank you for your time.

Amanda Doyle, National Director of Primary Care and Community Services, NHS England

Emma Rourke, Acting National Statistician, Office for National Statistics

Dear ((firstName)),

The Office for National Statistics (ONS) is an independent government department and the UK’s largest provider of official statistics.

We are running the monthly online Health Insight Survey on behalf of NHS England. This survey gathers feedback every four weeks on your experiences accessing NHS healthcare services in England, and we would like you to be a part of it.

In a few days, you will receive instructions by text on how to sign up.

Find out more about the Health Insight Survey on the ONS website at https://www.ons.gov.uk/healthinsightsurvey

Thank you from NHS England and the Office for National Statistics.

Dear ((firstName)),

We recently messaged you that the Office for National Statistics is running the online Health Insight Survey, and we would like you to be a part of it. The survey gathers feedback every four weeks on your experiences of NHS healthcare services in England, including your GP practice, pharmacy, community and dental services.

To sign up or find out more visit https://studies.ons.gov.uk/s/healthinsightsurvey2/

If you need advice or help, email health.studies@ons.gov.uk or call us free on 0808 196 1270.

Thank you from NHS England and the Office for National Statistics.

Dear ((firstName)),

We are messaging to let you know that you only have until Tuesday 9 September to sign up to the online Health Insight Survey. If you have already completed the survey, thank you. If not, we have included a link to the survey so you can sign up.

To sign up or find out more visit https://studies.ons.gov.uk/s/healthinsightsurvey2/

If you need advice or help, email health.studies@ons.gov.uk or call us free on 0808 196 1270.

Thank you from NHS England and the Office for National Statistics.

subject.S: Take part in the Health Insight Survey

message.S:
Dear ((firstName)) ((lastName)),

We recently emailed you that the Office for National Statistics is running the online Health Insight Survey, and we would like you to be a part of it. The survey gathers feedback every four weeks on your experiences of NHS healthcare services in England. This includes your GP practice, hospital waiting lists, community health services, pharmacy and dental services.

##Why should you take part?  
Your answers will help improve healthcare facilities and services local to you, impacting the future of the NHS in England.

##How to take part online  
Complete the steps below on your computer, tablet or smartphone.
1. Go to [https://studies.ons.gov.uk/s/healthinsightsurvey1/](https://studies.ons.gov.uk/s/healthinsightsurvey1/)
2. Complete the survey.
3. Select “Finish survey”.

##How to take part on the phone  
To take part over the phone, call us free on 0808 196 1270.
If you need advice or help, email [health.studies@ons.gov.uk](health.studies@ons.gov.uk).

The information you give us is protected by law and is treated as confidential.

##How long does it take?  
The survey takes between 5 and 10 minutes to finish.

##Who should take part?  
Only you can take part in this survey. No other person should take your place.

##When should I complete it by?  
You have until Tuesday 9 September to sign up. This initial short survey asks questions about who you are and where you live.

##What happens next?  
You will receive a ‘Welcome’ email confirming your participation in the survey, in early October.

We will ask you to complete a 5-to-10-minute online survey approximately every four weeks starting later in October.

##Don’t miss the chance to have your say about your local NHS services.

Thank you for your time.

Amanda Doyle, National Director of Primary Care and Community Services, NHS England

Emma Rourke, Acting National Statistician, Office for National Statistics

subject.S: Have your say about NHS care

message.S:
Dear ((firstName)) ((lastName)),

The Office for National Statistics (ONS) is an independent government department and the UK’s largest provider of official statistics. We collect and publish official statistics about our society and economy, and we run the census every 10 years. We are running the monthly online Health Insight Survey on behalf of NHS England. This survey gathers feedback every four weeks on your experiences of accessing NHS healthcare services in England, and we would like you to be a part of it.

##Why should you take part?  
By taking part in the Health Insight Survey, you will help to make the NHS better for all. Your information will be used to improve people's access to, and experience of, care such as GP practices, hospital waiting lists, community health services, pharmacy and dental services.

##Who should take part?  
Only you can take part in this survey. No other person should take your place.

##What happens next?  
In a few days, you will receive instructions by email on how to sign up. We will ask you to fill out an initial short survey about you. After that, we will ask you to complete the Health Insight Survey approximately every four weeks.

The information you give us is protected by law and is treated as confidential.

##Need more info or help?  
Find out more about the Health Insight Survey on the ONS website at [https://www.ons.gov.uk/healthinsightsurvey](https://www.ons.gov.uk/healthinsightsurvey).

If you need advice or help, email [health.studies@ons.gov.uk](health.studies@ons.gov.uk) or call us free on 0808 196 1270.

Thank you for your time.

Amanda Doyle, National Director of Primary Care and Community Services, NHS England

Emma Rourke, Acting National Statistician, Office for National Statistics

subject.S: REMINDER – Confirm your address with NHS England

message.S:
Dear ((fullName))

## Confirm your address with NHS England 

We recently wrote to you to confirm if the home address the NHS holds for you is up to date. 

## Please ignore this reminder if you have previously responded. 

If you do not confirm your address details within 30 days, we will assume you have moved. We will begin the process of removing you from your GP surgery’s patient list. 

This means you will no longer be registered with a GP surgery. You will not get important information about your healthcare. 

The NHS currently holds the following address for you: 

## ((address)) 

Do not reply to this email as your response will not be processed. 

## If your address information is correct 

Please complete one of the following options: 

## Option 1 

Select the link and complete the online form to confirm your address. You will need: 

* your reference number ((PCSERef)) 

* NHS number ((nhsNumber)). 

[https://pcse.england.nhs.uk/contact-us/patient-registrations-enquiry-categories/list-cleansing-patients-only](https://pcse.england.nhs.uk/contact-us/patient-registrations-enquiry-categories/list-cleansing-patients-only)

## Option 2 

Text YES((PCSERef)) to 07860 055388 (usual contract charges will apply). 

## If your address information is incorrect 

* You may need to register with a new GP surgery. You can use [Find a GP](https://www.nhs.uk/service-search/find-a-gp/) to look for a practice in your area. You can also contact your GP surgery to update your address. 

* If you have left the United Kingdom and you do not plan to return in 3 months, you need to call your GP and ask them to remove you from their patient list. 

This message has also been sent to you in a letter. 

Tell us about your experience of confirming or updating your address by completing a [short survey](https://feedback.digital.nhs.uk/jfe/form/SV_23vNIxwRjSFmXFY). 

Thank you for taking the time to respond to this request. 

Yours sincerely 
Primary Care Support England 
https://pcse.england.nhs.uk/organisations/public/ 

---

# Your NHS cervical screening result

Dear ((firstName)) ((lastName)),

Thank you for attending your cervical screening.

## Your result and what it means

Your result shows that you do not have human papillomavirus (HPV). This is called an "HPV negative" result.

This means your risk of cervical cancer is very low and there is no need to check for abnormal cell changes, even if you have had these in the past.

## Your next cervical screening test

Your next cervical screening test is due on or around ((next_test_due_date)). We will invite you nearer the time.

## More information

Cervical screening is the best way to protect yourself against cervical cancer, however no screening test is 100% reliable. 

There is a small chance that screening may not pick up an HPV infection or abnormal cells (a "false negative" result).

There is also a small risk of abnormal cells developing and turning into cancer in between screening tests. 

Speak to a GP as soon as possible if you have any of the following symptoms, regardless of your cervical screening history:

• vaginal bleeding that’s unusual for you – including bleeding during or after sex, between your periods or after the menopause, or heavier periods than usual 
• changes to your vaginal discharge 
• pain during sex 
• pain in your lower back, between your hip bones (pelvis), or in your lower tummy

Learn more about [human papillomavirus](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/human-papilloma-virus-hpv/).

Learn more about [NHS cervical screening](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/cervical-screening/).

If you have any questions about your test result, contact your GP or the person who took your last test.

[Read about how we use and protect your information](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/patient-confidentiality-in-nhs-population-screening-programmes), or [opt out](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/opting-out-of-the-nhs-population-screening-programmes/opting-out-of-screening).

# Your NHS cervical screening result

Dear ((firstName)) ((lastName)),

Thank you for attending your cervical screening.

## Your result and what it means

Your result shows that you have human papillomavirus (HPV). This is called an "HPV positive" result.

Because we found HPV in your sample, we also checked for abnormal cervical cells. The result shows you have abnormal cells, but it’s likely they did not come from your cervix.

This means your GP or the person who took your test will refer you to a local gynaecology clinic for further tests.

Contact your GP surgery to confirm they have referred you. If you are not registered with a GP, contact the place where you had your test instead.

## Your next cervical screening test

Because you have HPV, your next cervical screening will be on or around ((next_test_due_date)). We will invite you nearer the time.

It is important you attend your next screening so we can check if your immune system has cleared the HPV.

Although there are no treatments for HPV, your body will clear most HPV infections by itself within 2 years without any problems.
 
## What is HPV?

HPV is the name of a very common group of viruses that are spread through skin-to-skin contact of the genital area or by sharing sex toys.

It can stay in the body for many years and does not usually cause any symptoms. Most people do not realise they have it, and this means it can be hard to know when you got it or who you got it from.

Most people will get some type of HPV in their life. There is no need for you to tell anyone you have HPV if you do not want to.
 
Certain "high-risk" types of HPV can start to cause abnormal cells if your body does not clear them. These cells can sometimes turn into cancer. However, they can be treated very effectively before that happens.

[Find more information about HPV](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/human-papilloma-virus-hpv/).

## Protecting yourself and others from HPV

Condoms help protect against the spread of HPV, but they do not give full protection as they do not cover all the skin around the genitals.

The HPV vaccine protects against the types of HPV that cause most cases of cervical cancer. However, it does not protect against all types of HPV, so it is important you attend cervical screening appointments even if you’ve been vaccinated.

[Find more about the HPV vaccine and who can have it](https://www.nhs.uk/vaccinations/hpv-vaccine/).

## More information

Speak to a GP as soon as possible if you have any of the following symptoms, regardless of your cervical screening history:

• vaginal bleeding that’s unusual for you – including bleeding during or after sex, between your periods or after the menopause, or heavier periods than usual 
• changes to your vaginal discharge 
• pain during sex 
• pain in your lower back, between your hip bones (pelvis), or in your lower tummy

Learn more about [NHS cervical screening](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/cervical-screening/).

If you have any questions about your test result, contact your GP or the person who took your last test.

[Read about how we use and protect your information](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/patient-confidentiality-in-nhs-population-screening-programmes), or [opt out](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/opting-out-of-the-nhs-population-screening-programmes/opting-out-of-screening).

# Your NHS cervical screening result

## Your result and what it means

Unfortunately, we were not able to get any results from your screening sample. 

This does not mean there is anything wrong. It means the laboratory could not get a clear HPV result from your sample.

This means you need to have a repeat test in 3 months. 

## Your next cervical screening test

## More information

* vaginal bleeding – bleeding during or after sex, between your periods or after the menopause
* pain during sex

# Your NHS cervical screening invite

Dear ((firstName)) ((lastName)),

We are writing to invite you for your NHS cervical screening (previously called the ‘smear test’). 

We offer screening to all women and people with a cervix, aged 25 to 64, to help prevent cervical cancer and to save lives.

## How to book your appointment

You can contact a local GP surgery to book an appointment with them but you will need to register with them first. [Find more information about registering with a GP surgery](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/gps/how-to-register-with-a-gp-surgery/).

Some sexual health clinics also offer cervical screening. [Contact your local sexual health clinic](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/sexual-health-services/find-a-sexual-health-clinic/) to find out more.

## Why should I book an appointment?

Cervical screening checks for certain types of human papillomavirus (HPV). These ‘high risk’ types of HPV can be found in over 99% of cervical cancers. 

If we find one of these HPV types in your screening sample, we then check for abnormal cell changes. 

By finding and treating these changes early, we can prevent most cases of cervical cancer.

You can get HPV the first time you have sexual contact, and you do not need to have penetrative sex to get it. 

You can have it even if you have had the same sexual partner for a long time or have not been sexually active for many years. 

You can still have HPV regardless of your sexual orientation or if you have had the HPV vaccine.

## Support if you are worried about cervical screening

Cervical screening appointments only take 5 to 10 minutes, but you can ask for a longer appointment if you would like more time. 

You can also ask for a female nurse or doctor and can bring someone else in the room with you for support. 

During your appointment, you can ask to lie in a different position and for a smaller speculum to make the test more comfortable for you.

For more information about what happens during a cervical screening appointment, HPV, and cervical cancer, [read our online leaflet on the GOV.UK website](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/cervical-screening-description-in-brief).

You can also [find advice and support on the GOV.UK website if you feel worried or need assistance attending cervical screening](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/cervical-screening-support-for-people-who-find-it-hard-to-attend).

## More information

The nurse or doctor who does your screening test will tell you how and when you can expect to get your result, and they will also be told your result. 

If you change your address or contact details, tell the GP surgery or sexual health clinic that tested you.

Speak to a GP as soon as possible if you have any of the following symptoms, regardless of your cervical screening history:

• vaginal bleeding that’s unusual for you – including bleeding during or after sex, between your periods or after the menopause, or heavier periods than usual 
• changes to your vaginal discharge 
• pain during sex 
• pain in your lower back, between your hip bones (pelvis), or in your lower tummy 

Learn more about [NHS cervical screening and HPV](https://www.nhs.uk/tests-and-treatments/cervical-screening/), including what happens at your appointment and how to book. 

If you have any concerns or questions about cervical screening, contact a sexual health clinic or GP surgery.

[Read about how we use and protect your information](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/patient-confidentiality-in-nhs-population-screening-programmes), or [opt out](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/opting-out-of-the-nhs-population-screening-programmes/opting-out-of-screening).

Certain "high-risk" types of HPV can start to cause abnormal cells if your body does not clear them. These cells can sometimes turn into cancer. However, they can be treated very effectively before that happens.

[Find more information about HPV](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/human-papilloma-virus-hpv/).

**Protecting yourself and others from HPV**

Condoms help protect against the spread of HPV, but they do not give full protection as they do not cover all the skin around the genitals.

The HPV vaccine protects against the types of HPV that cause most cases of cervical cancer. However, it does not protect against all types of HPV, so it is important you attend cervical screening appointments even if you’ve been vaccinated.

[Find more about the HPV vaccine and who can have it](https://www.nhs.uk/vaccinations/hpv-vaccine/).

**More information**

Speak to a GP as soon as possible if you have any of the following symptoms, regardless of your cervical screening history:

• vaginal bleeding that’s unusual for you – including bleeding during or after sex, between your periods or after the menopause, or heavier periods than usual 
• changes to your vaginal discharge 
• pain during sex 
• pain in your lower back, between your hip bones (pelvis), or in your lower tummy

Learn more about [NHS cervical screening](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/cervical-screening/).

If you have any questions about your test result, contact your GP or the person who took your last test.

[Read about how we use and protect your information](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/patient-confidentiality-in-nhs-population-screening-programmes), or [opt out](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/opting-out-of-the-nhs-population-screening-programmes/opting-out-of-screening).

# Your NHS cervical screening invite

Dear ((firstName)) ((lastName)),

We are writing to invite you for your NHS cervical screening (previously called the ‘smear test’). 

We offer screening to all women and people with a cervix, aged 25 to 64, to help prevent cervical cancer and to save lives.

## How to book your appointment

Contact your GP surgery to book a cervical screening appointment.

Some sexual health clinics also offer cervical screening. [Contact your local sexual health clinic](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/sexual-health-services/find-a-sexual-health-clinic/) to find out more.

## Why should I book an appointment?

Cervical screening checks for certain types of human papillomavirus (HPV). These ‘high risk’ types of HPV can be found in over 99% of cervical cancers. 

If we find one of these HPV types in your screening sample, we then check for abnormal cell changes. 

By finding and treating these changes early, we can prevent most cases of cervical cancer.

You can get HPV the first time you have sexual contact, and you do not need to have penetrative sex to get it. 

You can have it even if you have had the same sexual partner for a long time or have not been sexually active for many years. 

You can still have HPV regardless of your sexual orientation or if you have had the HPV vaccine.

## Support if you are worried about cervical screening

Cervical screening appointments only take 5 to 10 minutes, but you can ask for a longer appointment if you would like more time. 

You can also ask for a female nurse or doctor and can bring someone else in the room with you for support. 

During your appointment, you can ask to lie in a different position and for a smaller speculum to make the test more comfortable for you.

For more information about what happens during a cervical screening appointment, HPV, and cervical cancer, [read our online leaflet on the GOV.UK website](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/cervical-screening-description-in-brief).

You can also [find advice and support on the GOV.UK website if you feel worried or need assistance attending cervical screening](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/cervical-screening-support-for-people-who-find-it-hard-to-attend).

## More information

The nurse or doctor who does your screening test will tell you how and when you can expect to get your result, and they will also be told your result. 

Tell your GP surgery if you change your address or contact details.

Speak to a GP as soon as possible if you have any of the following symptoms, regardless of your cervical screening history:

• vaginal bleeding that’s unusual for you – including bleeding during or after sex, between your periods or after the menopause, or heavier periods than usual 
• changes to your vaginal discharge 
• pain during sex 
• pain in your lower back, between your hip bones (pelvis), or in your lower tummy 

Learn more about [NHS cervical screening and HPV](https://www.nhs.uk/tests-and-treatments/cervical-screening/), including what happens at your appointment and how to book. 

If you have any concerns or questions about cervical screening, speak with a GP.

[Read about how we use and protect your information](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/patient-confidentiality-in-nhs-population-screening-programmes), or [opt out](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/opting-out-of-the-nhs-population-screening-programmes/opting-out-of-screening).

## Your NHS cervical screening result

Dear ((firstName)) ((lastName)),

Thank you for attending your cervical screening.

**Your result and what it means**

Unfortunately, we were not able to get any results from your screening sample. 

This does not mean there is anything wrong. It means the laboratory could not get a clear HPV result from your sample.

This means you need to have a repeat test in 3 months. 

**Your next cervical screening test**

Your repeat screening test is due on or around ((next_test_due_date)). We will invite you nearer the time. 

You cannot take another test before then as your body needs this time to make new cells before another sample is taken.

**More information**

Speak to a GP as soon as possible if you have any of the following symptoms, regardless of your cervical screening history:

• vaginal bleeding that’s unusual for you – including bleeding during or after sex, between your periods or after the menopause, or heavier periods than usual 
• changes to your vaginal discharge 
• pain during sex 
• pain in your lower back, between your hip bones (pelvis), or in your lower tummy

Learn more about [NHS cervical screening](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/cervical-screening/).

If you have any questions about your test result, contact your GP or the person who took your last test.

[Read about how we use and protect your information](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/patient-confidentiality-in-nhs-population-screening-programmes), or [opt out](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/opting-out-of-the-nhs-population-screening-programmes/opting-out-of-screening).

# Your NHS cervical screening result

Dear ((firstName)) ((lastName)),

Thank you for completing the human papillomavirus (HPV) self-screening kit for cervical screening.

## Your result and what it means

Your result shows that you do not have human papillomavirus (HPV). This is called an "HPV negative" result.

This means your risk of cervical cancer is very low and there is no need to check for abnormal cell changes, even if you have had these in the past.

Your GP will be told your result. You do not need to do anything further.

## Your next cervical screening test

You will no longer be invited for cervical screening because you will be over the age of 65 when your next test is due.

You are highly unlikely to develop cervical cancer if you are 65 and over and do not have a recent history of abnormal screening results.

## More information

Cervical screening is the best way to protect yourself against cervical cancer, however no screening test is 100% reliable. 

There is a small chance that screening may not pick up an HPV infection or abnormal cells (a "false negative" result).

There is also a small risk of abnormal cells developing and turning into cancer in between screening tests. 

Speak to a GP as soon as possible if you have any of the following symptoms, regardless of your cervical screening history:

• vaginal bleeding that’s unusual for you – including bleeding during or after sex, between your periods or after the menopause, or heavier periods than usual 

• changes to your vaginal discharge 

• pain during sex

• pain in your lower back, between your hip bones (pelvis), or in your lower tummy

Learn more about [NHS cervical screening](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/cervical-screening/).

If you think our information is incorrect, or you have any questions about your test result, contact your GP or the person who took your last test.

[Read about how we use and protect your information](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/patient-confidentiality-in-nhs-population-screening-programmes), or [opt out](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/opting-out-of-the-nhs-population-screening-programmes/opting-out-of-screening).

# Your NHS cervical screening reminder

Dear ((firstName)) ((lastName)),

A few months ago we invited you for your NHS cervical screening (previously called the ‘smear test’). 

We offer screening to all women and people with a cervix, aged 25 to 64, to help prevent cervical cancer and to save lives.

If you have had your cervical screening test in recent weeks, please ignore this message. 

## How to book your appointment

You can contact a local GP surgery to book an appointment with them but you will need to register with them first. [Find more information about registering with a GP surgery](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/gps/how-to-register-with-a-gp-surgery/).

Some sexual health clinics also offer cervical screening. [Contact your local sexual health clinic](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/sexual-health-services/find-a-sexual-health-clinic/) to find out more.

If you were not able to attend or missed your last cervical screening invite, you can still book an appointment.

## Why should I book an appointment?

Cervical screening checks for certain types of human papillomavirus (HPV). These ‘high risk’ types of HPV can be found in over 99% of cervical cancers. 

If we find one of these HPV types in your screening sample, we then check for abnormal cell changes. 

By finding and treating these changes early, we can prevent most cases of cervical cancer.

You can get HPV the first time you have sexual contact, and you do not need to have penetrative sex to get it. 

You can have it even if you have had the same sexual partner for a long time or have not been sexually active for many years. 

You can still have HPV regardless of your sexual orientation or if you have had the HPV vaccine.

## Support if you are worried about cervical screening

Cervical screening appointments only take 5 to 10 minutes, but you can ask for a longer appointment if you would like more time. 

You can also ask for a female nurse or doctor and can bring someone else in the room with you for support. 

During your appointment, you can ask to lie in a different position and for a smaller speculum to make the test more comfortable for you.

For more information about what happens during a cervical screening appointment, HPV, and cervical cancer, [read our online leaflet on the GOV.UK website](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/cervical-screening-description-in-brief).

You can also [find advice and support on the GOV.UK website if you feel worried or need assistance attending cervical screening](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/cervical-screening-support-for-people-who-find-it-hard-to-attend).

## More information

The nurse or doctor who does your screening test will tell you how and when you can expect to get your result, and they will also be told your result. 

If you change your address or contact details, tell the GP surgery or sexual health clinic that tested you.

Speak to a GP as soon as possible if you have any of the following symptoms, regardless of your cervical screening history:

• vaginal bleeding that’s unusual for you – including bleeding during or after sex, between your periods or after the menopause, or heavier periods than usual 
• changes to your vaginal discharge 
• pain during sex 
• pain in your lower back, between your hip bones (pelvis), or in your lower tummy 

Learn more about [NHS cervical screening and HPV](https://www.nhs.uk/tests-and-treatments/cervical-screening/), including what happens at your appointment and how to book. 

If you have any concerns or questions about cervical screening, contact a sexual health clinic or GP surgery.

[Read about how we use and protect your information](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/patient-confidentiality-in-nhs-population-screening-programmes), or [opt out](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/opting-out-of-the-nhs-population-screening-programmes/opting-out-of-screening).

# Your NHS cervical screening result

Dear ((firstName)) ((lastName)),

Thank you for completing the human papillomavirus (HPV) self-screening kit for cervical screening. 

## Your result and what it means

Your result shows that you do not have human papillomavirus (HPV). This is called an "HPV negative" result.

This means your risk of cervical cancer is very low and there is no need to check for abnormal cell changes, even if you have had these in the past.

Your GP will be told your result. You do not need to do anything further.

## Your next cervical screening test

Your next cervical screening test is due on or around ((next_test_due_date)). We will invite you nearer the time.

## More information

Cervical screening is the best way to protect yourself against cervical cancer, however no screening test is 100% reliable. 

There is a small chance that screening may not pick up an HPV infection or abnormal cells (a "false negative" result).

There is also a small risk of abnormal cells developing and turning into cancer in between screening tests. 

Speak to a GP as soon as possible if you have any of the following symptoms, regardless of your cervical screening history:

• vaginal bleeding that’s unusual for you – including bleeding during or after sex, between your periods or after the menopause, or heavier periods than usual 

• changes to your vaginal discharge 

• pain during sex 

• pain in your lower back, between your hip bones (pelvis), or in your lower tummy

Learn more about [human papillomavirus] (https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/human-papilloma-virus-hpv/).

Learn more about [NHS cervical screening](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/cervical-screening/).

If you have any questions about your test result, contact your GP.

[Read about how we use and protect your information](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/patient-confidentiality-in-nhs-population-screening-programmes), or [opt out](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/opting-out-of-the-nhs-population-screening-programmes/opting-out-of-screening).

## Your NHS cervical screening result

Dear ((firstName)) ((lastName)),

Thank you for attending your cervical screening.

**Your result and what it means**

Your result shows that you have human papillomavirus (HPV). This is called an "HPV positive" result.

Because we found HPV in your sample, we also checked for abnormal cervical cells. The result shows you did not have any abnormal cells in your sample. 

This result means you are currently at low risk of cervical cancer.

**Your next cervical screening test**

Because you have HPV, your next cervical screening will be on or around ((next_test_due_date)). We will invite you nearer the time.

It is important you attend your next screening so we can check if your immune system has cleared the HPV. 

Although there are no treatments for HPV, your body will clear most HPV infections by itself within 2 years without any problems.
 
**What is HPV?**

HPV is the name of a very common group of viruses that are spread through skin-to-skin contact of the genital area or by sharing sex toys. 

It can stay in the body for many years and does not usually cause any symptoms. Most people do not realise they have it, and this means it can be hard to know when you got it or who you got it from. 

Most people will get some type of HPV in their life. There is no need for you to tell anyone you have HPV if you do not want to. 

Certain "high-risk" types of HPV can start to cause abnormal cells if your body does not clear them. These cells can sometimes turn into cancer. However, they can be treated very effectively before that happens.

[Find more information about HPV](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/human-papilloma-virus-hpv/).

**Protecting yourself and others from HPV**

Condoms help protect against the spread of HPV, but they do not give full protection as they do not cover all the skin around the genitals.

The HPV vaccine protects against the types of HPV that cause most cases of cervical cancer. However, it does not protect against all types of HPV, so it is important you attend cervical screening appointments even if you’ve been vaccinated.

[Find more about the HPV vaccine and who can have it](https://www.nhs.uk/vaccinations/hpv-vaccine/).

**More information**

Speak to a GP as soon as possible if you have any of the following symptoms, regardless of your cervical screening history:

• vaginal bleeding that’s unusual for you – including bleeding during or after sex, between your periods or after the menopause, or heavier periods than usual 
• changes to your vaginal discharge 
• pain during sex 
• pain in your lower back, between your hip bones (pelvis), or in your lower tummy

Learn more about [NHS cervical screening](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/cervical-screening/).

If you have any questions about your test result, contact your GP or the person who took your last test.

[Read about how we use and protect your information](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/patient-confidentiality-in-nhs-population-screening-programmes), or [opt out](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/opting-out-of-the-nhs-population-screening-programmes/opting-out-of-screening).

Dear {{firstName}} {{lastName}},

Our records show you have not had a cervical screening test since your last invitation.

Cervical screening is only offered to people from the age of 25 to 64 years. Because of this, you will no longer receive cervical screening invitations. 

However, you can choose to have a final test if you have not been screened since your 60th birthday. Speak to a GP or sexual health clinic to arrange this – you do not need an invitation.

## Why am I not invited once I turn 65?

It is normal to stop receiving cervical screening invitations once you turn 65 as it is very unlikely you'll get cervical cancer if your recent screening tests did not find anything.

Only people who had a recent abnormal test are invited after they’ve turned 65.

## More information

Regardless of your cervical screening history, speak to a GP as soon as possible if you are worried about cervical cancer or have any of the following symptoms that are new or unusual for you:

* vaginal bleeding – bleeding during or after sex, between your periods or after the menopause
* pain during sex
* vaginal discharge that is smelly and heavier than usual

These symptoms can be caused by other conditions. Having them does not mean you have cervical cancer, but it’s still important to get them checked by a GP.

Learn more about [NHS cervical screening](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/cervical-screening/).

If you think our information is incorrect or you have any questions, contact a GP or your nearest sexual health clinic.

[Read about how we use and protect your information](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/patient-confidentiality-in-nhs-population-screening-programmes).

# Your NHS cervical screening reminder

Dear ((firstName)) ((lastName)),

A few months ago we invited you for your NHS cervical screening (previously called the ‘smear test’). 

We offer screening to all women and people with a cervix, aged 25 to 64, to help prevent cervical cancer and to save lives.

If you have had your cervical screening test in recent weeks, please ignore this message.

Cervical screening checks for certain types of human papillomavirus (HPV). These ‘high risk’ types of HPV can be found in over 99% of cervical cancers. 

If we find one of these HPV types in your screening sample, we then check for abnormal cell changes. 

By finding and treating these changes early, we can prevent most cases of cervical cancer.

You can get HPV the first time you have sexual contact, and you do not need to have penetrative sex to get it. 

You can have it even if you have had the same sexual partner for a long time or have not been sexually active for many years. 

You can still have HPV regardless of your sexual orientation or if you have had the HPV vaccine.

## Support if you are worried about cervical screening

You can book a free NHS respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) vaccine because of your age. Find a pharmacy offering RSV vaccines at www.nhs.uk/find-rsv or contact your GP surgery. subject.S: Booking your NHS respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) vaccine

message.S:
Dear ((fullName)), 
 
You can book a free NHS RSV vaccine because of your age. 
 
RSV is a virus that affects the airways and lungs and can make it difficult to breathe. Your age group has a higher risk of getting seriously ill from RSV infection.
 
## How to get your RSV vaccine
 
Contact your GP surgery to make an appointment.
 
If they cannot book you in now, please ask when they will have more RSV appointments. 
 
If you are aged 80 years, your last chance to get the RSV vaccine is 31 August 2025.
 
## Why the NHS is offering the RSV vaccine
 
RSV infections occur all year round and can be hard to avoid. Every year, thousands of older adults need hospital care for RSV, and some of them die. RSV infection can cause shortness of breath and lead to pneumonia and other life-threatening conditions. 
 
Having the RSV vaccine reduces your risk of severe symptoms. Just 1 dose gives most people good protection for a few years.
 
## More information
 
The RSV vaccine is different to the COVID-19 and flu vaccines. Each vaccine protects you against different respiratory infections. It’s important you have these vaccines when you are offered them. You can read more at [www.nhs.uk/rsv-vaccine](www.nhs.uk/rsv-vaccine). 
 
For a guide to the RSV vaccine for older adults, go to [www.gov.uk/rsv-vaccine](www.gov.uk/rsv-vaccine). For information in easy read and other languages and formats, go to [www.england.nhs.uk/rsv-invites](www.england.nhs.uk/rsv-invites).
 
## Other NHS vaccines for people aged under 80
 
If you haven't already, you can also get free NHS pneumococcal and shingles vaccines. Contact your GP surgery if you missed either vaccine. For details, go to [www.nhs.uk/vaccinations](www.nhs.uk/vaccinations).
 
Yours sincerely,  
 
NHS England Vaccination Team

Data Protection: NHS England is responsible for processing your personal data. This is for the purpose of national vaccination programmes. To find out more, you can access our privacy notice at [www.england.nhs.uk/privacy-notice](www.england.nhs.uk/privacy-notice).

**How to get your RSV vaccine**

You can get your RSV vaccine in one of the following ways:

* [Book a pharmacy appointment](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/pharmacies/book-or-cancel-an-rsv-vaccination-at-a-pharmacy/)   

* [Find a pharmacy walk-in site](https://www.nhs.uk/service-search/vaccination-and-booking-services/find-a-pharmacy-where-you-can-get-a-free-rsv-vaccination)  

* Contact your GP surgery 

If your GP surgery cannot book you in now, please ask when they will have more RSV appointments. 

If you are aged 80 years, your last chance to get the RSV vaccine is **31 August 2025.**

**Why the NHS is offering the RSV vaccine**

RSV infections occur all year round and can be hard to avoid. 
 
Every year, thousands of older adults need hospital care for RSV, and some of them die. RSV infection can cause shortness of breath and lead to pneumonia and other life-threatening conditions. 

Having the RSV vaccine reduces your risk of severe symptoms. Just **1 dose** gives most people good protection for a few years.

**More information** 

The RSV vaccine is different to the COVID-19 and flu vaccines. Each vaccine protects you against different respiratory infections. It’s important you have these vaccines when you are offered them. You can [read more on the RSV vaccine]( https://www.nhs.uk/vaccinations/rsv-vaccine/) on NHS.UK. 

A [guide to the RSV vaccine for older adults]( https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/respiratory-syncytial-virus-rsv-vaccination-for-older-adults) is available on GOV.UK. Information is also available in [easy read and other languages and formats]( https://www.england.nhs.uk/publication/respiratory-syncytial-virus-vaccination-invitation/). 

**Other NHS vaccines for people aged under 80** 

If you haven't already, you can also get free NHS pneumococcal and shingles vaccines. Contact your GP surgery if you missed either vaccine. [For details](https://www.nhs.uk/vaccinations/), go to NHS.UK.  

NHS England Vaccination Team  

Data Protection: Read NHS England’s [privacy notice]( https://www.england.nhs.uk/contact-us/privacy-notice/).
